newsitem.title: INDIA: India's telecom firms target U.S. retail investors.
newsitem.headline: India's telecom firms target U.S. retail investors.

text.p: Indian telecommunications firms -- lured by the world's largest capital market -- are opting to raise equity by issuing American Depositary Receipts (ADRs), investment bankers said on Tuesday.
"ADRs allow a company to tap a much broader investor base and a listing in the U.S. gives the company higher visibility," said an investment banker at a U.S. bank in Bombay.
Investment bankers say fledgling Indian telecom companies including Hutchison Max Telecom, Bharati Telecom and a BPL group firm plan to raise some $500 million through ADRs.
Indian firms have traditionally raised international equity through global depositary receipts (GDRs) which do not have access to retail investors across the United States.
But aggressive marketing by American investment banks promising greater access to investors and the prestige of a Nasdaq listing are making some firms opt for ADRs.

"Since an ADR requires a much higher standard of accounting and disclosure than a GDR and since it undergoes an extensive due-diligence process, it is seen as an investment that is potentially more attractive," said the banker at the U.S. investment bank.
A presentation by Citibank N.A. said U.S. investments in international equities rose sharply to an estimated $350 billion in 1995 from $17 billion in 1981.

"ADRs allow access to retail investors and the smaller, more aggressive growth funds which don't qualify for QIB (qualified institutional buyer) status," said an investment banker associated with one of the forthcoming issues.
British-based investment banks are fighting back.
A written presentation by a British-based firm questioned the necessity of targeting U.S. retail investors.
"Focusing on QIBs is more rewarding than blanket bombing the retail investors," the presentation said.
It said U.S. investors regard Mexico as a role model for emerging markets worldwide but are cautious due to repeated losses in Mexico and Latin America.

British-based investment bankers say American retail investors are typically short-term players with a limited understanding of markets outside the United States and add that the costs and legal ramifications of an ADR far outweigh its advantages.
They estimate direct costs (excluding listing fees and roadshow costs) of ADRs to be sharply higher at $1.0 to $1.5 million against $350,000-$500,000 for GDRs.
"The fees are higher but the company has a choice and doesn't have to go with the adviser that offers a U.S. listing," said a Singapore-based U.S. investment banker.
